subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Something interesting ...

John S I just recently started a sister group where all we do is record wit=
h Jesus=C2=A0to get messages.
=C2=A0
Perhaps one of us, Bruce, Steve or Fra=
nk or I would even volunteer, should set up a sister group where all member=
s do is record with the dead to find out how they get their messags to show=
 up in the radio noise where our recorders pick it up.
=C2=A0
All recorded =
information can be used in our research to build a better device. Our group=
s today house all kinds of messages, but to set up a specialized group wher=
e the sole mission is to get info how they communicate to us, and how they =
advise we build a better device, this group and information received would =
be very beneficial to all of you that have the electronic skills to build a=
nd tweak.
=C2=A0
The key is only messages get posted that=C2=A0result from =
asking questions to the other side how they communicate with us using our r=
adios, recorders or even EVP-Maker.
=C2=A0
If no one wants to do this, I wi=
ll be happy to set that up with moderators. Please let me know.
=C2=A0Micha=
el Edwards 


http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/SDWR-SpeakingToTheDeadWith=
Radios-/
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/EVPMessagesWithJesusChrist/ 




___=
_____________________________
From: Zack Widup <w9sz.zack@...>
To: EV=
P-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Fri, June 11, 2010 3:35:57 PM
Subject: Re: [EVP=
-ITC] Something interesting ...

=C2=A0 
That's all fascinating. It makes s=
ense to me.

I have gotten several EVP recordings in which a name was given=
. In all cases the name is not a name that was known by any of the living p=
eople present and there is no particular reason for anyone there to be thin=
king of that name. In one case the name was verified in old=C2=A0records=C2=
=A0as a person present in that location many years ago (but we certainly di=
dn't know that at the time we were there). In another case we're still=C2=
=A0trying to find out if anyone by that name was in that area within the la=
st 150 years.

Zack

=C2=A0
On Fri, Jun 11, 2010 at 1:59 PM, John S <phenom=
_investigator @...> wrote:

=C2=A0 
>I was listening to Tom's very cl=
ear recording and decided to put it through Audacity
>so I could view the s=
pectrum. Usually recordings have far too much noise for this
>to work well,=
 which is why I like the clearer and cleaner recordings many people
>call '=
Class A'.=C2=A0 What I found got me to thinking and I want to=C2=A0share my=
 thoughts.
>
>First, it's helpful to know that I have quite a bit of profes=
sional experience studying
>spectra - from ULF up through sound and light a=
nd way into the region of radio
>waves and even cosmic radiation. I have st=
ared at more spectrum analyzers over
>the decades than I care to count. So =
when I realized what I was seeing in Tom's
>recording I was a bit surprised=
 I hadn't thought about it before.
>
>Usually when you look at a visual rep=
resentation of an audio recording, you can
>clearly see the noise with the =
signal superimposed atop it. The higher the noise
>level relative to the si=
gnal level, the lower the 'signal-to-noise' ratio which results
>in recordi=
ngs that are very hard to hear. In a normal recording, such as you might 
>=
make of yourself speaking into a microphone, there is a specific way the no=
ise
>band disappears when the signal level gets high enough. But more than =
that, 
>this only occurs when the signal is introduced in the early stages =
of audio 
>processing - a noisy amplifier for example looks completely diff=
erent than 
>a high level background noise with someone speaking over it. A=
nd that's 
>what is important here.
>
>What I noticed that got me thinking =
was that in the spectrum analysis, 
>the noise level was reasonable for thi=
s type of recording. And it was fairly
>constant. It was what I have come t=
o see in these recordings except that
>the signal to noise ratio was a bit =
better. Meaning the signal was a bit 
>clearer initially. When the sound (w=
hich seems to be a young girl's
>voice) begins, the noise level rapidly goe=
s down and almost completely
>vanishes while the signal goes high. This is =
why you can clearly hear
>the voice: the absence of noise as much as the si=
gnal level itself.
>
>Now here's what got me going. I realized that this sp=
ecific waveform
>suggests strongly that the point of influence is not deep =
inside the 
>electronics. Rather, it is at an exterior point, such as where=
 the signal
>first enters the system. And that would imply that something t=
owards
>the outer part of the electronics is being manipulated, and not the=
 
>recording media or anything near it. 
>
>This would also explain why voi=
ce phenomena can appear on different
>media and on different electronics su=
ch as transistor or solid state or
>vacuum tube. AAEVP has suggested, and b=
ased on this observation
>I would agree, that the probable point of influen=
ce is a junction near 
>the a front-end stage of an early amplifier circuit=
. Every electronic 
>system would have this in common.
>
>I have suggested =
before that I believe that at least some (probably 
>the higher quality) EV=
Ps may be due to operator PK influence.
>MicroPK is believed to operate at =
or near the molecular level as 
>evidenced by things such as healing. And h=
ealing agents have
>been identified who have many similar traits to PK agen=
ts. So
>it follows they may employ similar abilities and use similar 
>mech=
anisms.=C2=A0 This observation is entirely in line with this idea.
>
>Does =
this mean that in truth no discarnates are communicating?
>In a dramatic de=
monstration of who I really am, or more to the 
>point what I really believ=
e, let me say that I'm not yet sure.
>Maybe they are, and maybe they are no=
t. This evidence does
>not tell us that answer.
>
>This is similar to work =
in mediumship research. We have shown
>that mediums can receive information=
 they should not know in
>controlled laboratory conditions. But we don't kn=
ow scientifically
>where this information comes from. Apparitional experien=
ts are
>convinced they have seen or heard the dead, but apparitions of 
>th=
e living are quite common as well. The more you learn about
>this phenomena=
, the more you realize that many commoly 
>accepted=C2=A0explanation s fall=
 short when applied in general.
>
>As I wrote previously, the real issue is=
 that science today
>does=C2=A0 not have the understanding or the tools to =
properly 
>evaluate this data. Science cannot prove or disprove this 
>phen=
omena. Not today. An honest scientist (and skeptic)
>will tell you this is =
an unknown, an anomaly. And so, as
>folks here know, it comes down to belie=
f in the absence 
>of any protocol or experiment to clearly demonstrate the=

>source of these sounds.
>
>But I for one feel comfortable that higher qua=
lity recordings
>will help move us along, if for no other reason than we ca=
n 
>eliminate some variables. The analysis I mentioned can't 
>be done on n=
oisier recordings; it took a very quiet one to
>be able to see this clearly=
. And that's what triggered my 
>thoughts.
>
>I also noticed a tiny spike b=
efore and after the higher
>quality speech. To some this might suggest an e=
dit, 
>but in this case I don't think that happened - here's why.
>You can =
see the signal emerging from the noise when
>noise is still present and onl=
y when it achieves a certain
>level is the noise suppressed. Had this been =
an edit, 
>the noise level on this close a scrutiny would have 
>been a bit=
 more obvious - unless the editor got very lucky.
>But in consideration of =
how the voice appears and 
>also the fact that similar low-level spikes app=
ear 
>elsewhere in the recording, it would seem more likely
>that the spike=
s are artifacts of the tuning that's going
>on or some other random events.=

>
>Once again, this makes the case for me at least 
>for trying to get the=
 highest quality possible. These
>are the kinds of=C2=A0recordings which sc=
ientists may be 
>able to use sooner than later as understanding and 
>tool=
s inevitably improve.
>
>One last thought regarding the notion of PK as an =

>explanation. It is very important we come to understand
>PK well. Only th=
en might it actually be used in a 
>practical way. I'm sure you've heard or=
 thought about
>a world where you could literally turn things on and off
>w=
ith your mind. Or type simply by thinking about it.
>Believe it or not, one=
 way forward to such technology
>could well be through the understanding of=
 PK. So much
>of Parapsychology is actually exploring the leading edge
>(so=
me might say 'bleeding' edge) of science. It shows us
>where things might g=
o and, frankly, that is one interesting
>world at least for me. That's why =
I have been in the field
>for many decades.
>
>Apologies for the long post,=
 but I thought some might 
>find it useful and informative.
>
>

>
<DIV>That's all fascinating. It makes sense to me.</DIV>
<DIV> </DIV=
>
<DIV>I have gotten several EVP recordings in which a name was given. In a=
ll cases the name is not a name that was known by any of the living people =
present and there is no particular reason for anyone there to be thinking o=
f that name. In one case the name was verified in old records as =
a person present in that location many years ago (but we certainly didn't k=
now that at the time we were there). In another case we're still tryin=
g to find out if anyone by that name was in that area within the last 150 y=
ears.<BR></DIV>
<DIV>Zack</DIV>
<DIV><BR> </DIV>
<DIV class=3Dgmail_qu=
ote>On Fri, Jun 11, 2010 at 1:59 PM, John S <SPAN dir=3Dltr><<A href=3D"=
mailto:phenom_investigator@..." rel=3Dnofollow target=3D_blank ymailt=
o=3D"mailto:phenom_investigator@...">phenom_investigator @...</=
A>></SPAN> wrote:<BR>
<BLOCKQUOTE style=3D"BORDER-LEFT: #ccc 1px solid" =
class=3Dgmail_quote>
<DIV style=3D"BACKGROUND-COLOR: #fff"><SPAN> </SP=
AN> 
<DIV>
<DIV>
<DIV>
<P>
<DIV style=3D"FONT-FAMILY: arial, helvetica, san=
s-serif; FONT-SIZE: 10pt">
<DIV>I was listening to Tom's very clear recordi=
ng and decided to put it through Audacity</DIV>
<DIV>so I could view the sp=
ectrum. Usually recordings have far too much noise for this</DIV>
<DIV>to w=
ork well, which is why I like the clearer and cleaner recordings many peopl=
e</DIV>
<DIV>call 'Class A'.  What I found got me to thinking and I wa=
nt to share my thoughts.</DIV>
<DIV> </DIV>
<DIV>First, it's help=
ful to know that I have quite a bit of professional experience studying</DI=
V>
<DIV>spectra - from ULF up through sound and light and way into the regi=
on of radio</DIV>
<DIV>waves and even cosmic radiation. I have stared at mo=
re spectrum analyzers over</DIV>
<DIV>the decades than I care to count. So =
when I realized what I was seeing in Tom's</DIV>
<DIV>recording I was a bit=
 surprised I hadn't thought about it before.</DIV>
<DIV> </DIV>
<DIV>U=
sually when you look at a visual representation of an audio recording, you =
can</DIV>
<DIV>clearly see the noise with the signal superimposed atop it. =
The higher the noise</DIV>
<DIV>level relative to the signal level, the low=
er the 'signal-to-noise' ratio which results</DIV>
<DIV>in recordings that =
are very hard to hear. In a normal recording, such as you might </DIV>
<DIV=
>make of yourself speaking into a microphone, there is a specific way the n=
oise</DIV>
<DIV>band disappears when the signal level gets high enough. But=
 more than that, </DIV>
<DIV>this only occurs when the signal is introduced=
 in the early stages of audio </DIV>
<DIV>processing - a noisy amplifier fo=
r example looks completely different than </DIV>
<DIV>a high level backgrou=
nd noise with someone speaking over it. And that's </DIV>
<DIV>what is impo=
rtant here.</DIV>
<DIV> </DIV>
<DIV>What I noticed that got me thinkin=
g was that in the spectrum analysis, </DIV>
<DIV>the noise level was reason=
able for this type of recording. And it was fairly</DIV>
<DIV>constant. It =
was what I have come to see in these recordings except that</DIV>
<DIV>the =
signal to noise ratio was a bit better. Meaning the signal was a bit </DIV>=

<DIV>clearer initially. When the sound (which seems to be a young girl's</=
DIV>
<DIV>voice) begins, the noise level rapidly goes down and almost compl=
etely</DIV>
<DIV>vanishes while the signal goes high. This is why you can c=
learly hear</DIV>
<DIV>the voice: the absence of noise as much as the signa=
l level itself.</DIV>
<DIV> </DIV>
<DIV>Now here's what got me going. =
I realized that this specific waveform</DIV>
<DIV>suggests strongly that th=
e point of influence is not deep inside the </DIV>
<DIV>electronics. Rather=
, it is at an exterior point, such as where the signal</DIV>
<DIV>first ent=
ers the system. And that would imply that something towards</DIV>
<DIV>the =
outer part of the electronics is being manipulated, and not the </DIV>
<DIV=
>recording media or anything near it. </DIV>
<DIV> </DIV>
<DIV>This wo=
uld also explain why voice phenomena can appear on different</DIV>
<DIV>med=
ia and on different electronics such as transistor or solid state or</DIV>
=
<DIV>vacuum tube. AAEVP has suggested, and based on this observation</DIV>
=
<DIV>I would agree, that the probable point of influence is a junction near=
 </DIV>
<DIV>the a front-end stage of an early amplifier circuit. Every ele=
ctronic </DIV>
<DIV>system would have this in common.</DIV>
<DIV> </DI=
V>
<DIV>I have suggested before that I believe that at least some (probably=
 </DIV>
<DIV>the higher quality) EVPs may be due to operator PK influence.<=
/DIV>
<DIV>MicroPK is believed to operate at or near the molecular level as=
 </DIV>
<DIV>evidenced by things such as healing. And healing agents have</=
DIV>
<DIV>been identified who have many similar traits to PK agents. So</DI=
V>
<DIV>it follows they may employ similar abilities and use similar </DIV>=

<DIV>mechanisms.  This observation is entirely in line with this idea=
.</DIV>
<DIV> </DIV>
<DIV>Does this mean that in truth no discarnates =
are communicating?</DIV>
<DIV>In a dramatic demonstration of who I really a=
m, or more to the </DIV>
<DIV>point what I really believe, let me say that =
I'm not yet sure.</DIV>
<DIV>Maybe they are, and maybe they are not. This e=
vidence does</DIV>
<DIV>not tell us that answer.</DIV>
<DIV> </DIV>
<D=
IV>This is similar to work in mediumship research. We have shown</DIV>
<DIV=
>that mediums can receive information they should not know in</DIV>
<DIV>co=
ntrolled laboratory conditions. But we don't know scientifically</DIV>
<DIV=
>where this information comes from. Apparitional experients are</DIV>
<DIV>=
convinced they have seen or heard the dead, but apparitions of </DIV>
<DIV>=
the living are quite common as well. The more you learn about</DIV>
<DIV>th=
is phenomena, the more you realize that many commoly </DIV>
<DIV>accepted&n=
bsp;explanation s fall short when applied in general.</DIV>
<DIV> </DI=
V>
<DIV>As I wrote previously, the real issue is that science today</DIV>
<=
DIV>does  not have the understanding or the tools to properly </DIV>
<=
DIV>evaluate this data. Science cannot prove or disprove this </DIV>
<DIV>p=
henomena. Not today. An honest scientist (and skeptic)</DIV>
<DIV>will tell=
 you this is an unknown, an anomaly. And so, as</DIV>
<DIV>folks here know,=
 it comes down to belief in the absence </DIV>
<DIV>of any protocol or expe=
riment to clearly demonstrate the</DIV>
<DIV>source of these sounds.</DIV>
=
<DIV> </DIV>
<DIV>But I for one feel comfortable that higher quality r=
ecordings</DIV>
<DIV>will help move us along, if for no other reason than w=
e can </DIV>
<DIV>eliminate some variables. The analysis I mentioned can't =
</DIV>
<DIV>be done on noisier recordings; it took a very quiet one to</DIV=
>
<DIV>be able to see this clearly. And that's what triggered my </DIV>
<DI=
V>thoughts.</DIV>
<DIV> </DIV>
<DIV>I also noticed a tiny spike before=
 and after the higher</DIV>
<DIV>quality speech. To some this might suggest=
 an edit, </DIV>
<DIV>but in this case I don't think that happened - here's=
 why.</DIV>
<DIV>You can see the signal emerging from the noise when</DIV>
=
<DIV>noise is still present and only when it achieves a certain</DIV>
<DIV>=
level is the noise suppressed. Had this been an edit, </DIV>
<DIV>the noise=
 level on this close a scrutiny would have </DIV>
<DIV>been a bit more obvi=
ous - unless the editor got very lucky.</DIV>
<DIV>But in consideration of =
how the voice appears and </DIV>
<DIV>also the fact that similar low-level =
spikes appear </DIV>
<DIV>elsewhere in the recording, it would seem more li=
kely</DIV>
<DIV>that the spikes are artifacts of the tuning that's going</D=
IV>
<DIV>on or some other random events.</DIV>
<DIV> </DIV>
<DIV>Once =
again, this makes the case for me at least </DIV>
<DIV>for trying to get th=
e highest quality possible. These</DIV>
<DIV>are the kinds of recordin=
gs which scientists may be </DIV>
<DIV>able to use sooner than later as und=
erstanding and </DIV>
<DIV>tools inevitably improve.</DIV>
<DIV> </DIV=
>
<DIV>One last thought regarding the notion of PK as an </DIV>
<DIV>explan=
ation. It is very important we come to understand</DIV>
<DIV>PK well. Only =
then might it actually be used in a </DIV>
<DIV>practical way. I'm sure you=
've heard or thought about</DIV>
<DIV>a world where you could literally tur=
n things on and off</DIV>
<DIV>with your mind. Or type simply by thinking a=
bout it.</DIV>
<DIV>Believe it or not, one way forward to such technology</=
DIV>
<DIV>could well be through the understanding of PK. So much</DIV>
<DIV=
>of Parapsychology is actually exploring the leading edge</DIV>
<DIV>(some =
might say 'bleeding' edge) of science. It shows us</DIV>
<DIV>where things =
might go and, frankly, that is one interesting</DIV>
<DIV>world at least fo=
r me. That's why I have been in the field</DIV>
<DIV>for many decades.</DIV=
>
<DIV> </DIV>
<DIV>Apologies for the long post, but I thought some mi=
ght </DIV>
<DIV>find it useful and informative.</DIV>
<DIV> </DIV></DI=
V><BR>
